paragraphs.text: %md ## Association Rules (Market Basket Analysis) The Association Rules machine learning technique, also known as Market Basket Analysis, can also be used when looking for co-occurring items, states that lead to failures, or non-obvious events, e.g., as in manufacturing. In his notebook, you will build associations rules models using the Apriori algorithm with data from the SH schema (SH.SALES). All computation occurs inside Oracle Autonomous Database. Copyright (c) 2023 Oracle Corporation ###### The Universal Permissive License (UPL), Version 1.0 ---

msg.data:
Association Rules (Market Basket Analysis)

The Association Rules machine learning technique, also known as Market Basket Analysis, can also be used when looking for co-occurring items, states that lead to failures, or non-obvious events, e.g., as in manufacturing. In his notebook, you will build associations rules models using the Apriori algorithm with data from the SH schema (SH.SALES). All computation occurs inside Oracle Autonomous Database.

Copyright (c) 2023 Oracle Corporation

The Universal Permissive License (UPL), Version 1.0

paragraphs.title: Display SALES data
paragraphs.text:
%sql

-- Note that a transaction is defined by a set of products purchased for a given customer at a given time. 

SELECT CUST_ID, TIME_ID, PROD_ID, QUANTITY_SOLD, AMOUNT_SOLD, CHANNEL_ID, PROMO_ID 
FROM   SH.SALES
ORDER BY CUST_ID, TIME_ID, PROD_ID
FETCH FIRST 20 ROWS ONLY;

paragraphs.title: Prepare Sales transactional data for market basket analysis and create a SALES_TRANS_CUST view
paragraphs.text:
%script

-- Join data from the SH.SALES and SH.PRODUCTS tables to provide the product names and categories purchased by each customer

CREATE OR REPLACE VIEW SALES_TRANS_CUST AS
  SELECT DISTINCT CUST_ID, PROD_NAME, PROD_CATEGORY
    FROM (SELECT A.CUST_ID, B.PROD_NAME, B.PROD_CATEGORY
    FROM SH.SALES A, SH.PRODUCTS B
    WHERE A.PROD_ID = B.PROD_ID AND
      A.CUST_ID BETWEEN 100001 AND 104500);

msg.data:
View SALES_TRANS_CUST created.


---------------------------

paragraphs.title: Display view SALES_TRANS_CUST
paragraphs.text:
%sql

-- Display data from Sales Transactional Data view created above

SELECT * 
FROM SALES_TRANS_CUST
FETCH FIRST 20 ROWS ONLY;

paragraphs.text: %md ### Examples of possible setting overrides for Association Rules (A Priori) If the user does not override the default settings, then relevant settings are determined by the algorithm A complete list of settings can be found in the Documentation link: -- Algorithm Settings: Association Rules - A Priori -- Shared Settings: All algorithms -- Specify a row weight column v_setlst('ODMS_ROW_WEIGHT_COLUMN_NAME') := ''; -- Specify a missing value treatment method for the training data. This setting does not affect the scoring data. The default value is `ODMS_MISSING_VALUE_AUTO`. The option `ODMS_MISSING_VALUE_MEAN_MODE` replaces missing values with the mean (numeric attributes) or the mode (categorical attributes) both at build time and apply time where appropriate. The option `ODMS_MISSING_VALUE_AUTO` performs different strategies for different algorithms. When `ODMS_MISSING_VALUE_TREATMENT` is set to `ODMS_MISSING_VALUE_DELETE_ROW`, the rows in the training data that contain missing values are deleted. However, if you want to replicate this missing value treatment in the scoring data, then you must perform the transformation explicitly. v_setlst('ODMS_MISSING_VALUE_TREATMENT') : 'ODMS_MISSING_VALUE_AUTO'; -- Specify the Minimum support for association rules. The default value is 0.1. It requires a number between 0 and 1 (inclusive). v_setlst('ASSO_MIN_SUPPORT') := '0.1'; -- Specify the Minimum confidence for association rules. The default value is 0.1. It requires a number between 0 and 1 (inclusive). v_setlst('ASSO_MIN_CONFIDENCE') := '0.1'; -- Specify the Maximum rule length for association rules. The default value is 4. It requires a number between 2 and 20 (inclusive). v_setlst('ASSO_MAX_RULE_LENGTH') := '4'; -- Specify the name of a column that contains the items in a transaction. When you specify this setting, the algorithm expects the data to be presented in native transactional format, consisting of two columns: - Case ID, either categorical or numeric - Item ID, either categorical or numeric v_setlst('ODMS_ITEM_ID_COLUMN_NAME') := '';

msg.data:
Examples of possible setting overrides for Association Rules (A Priori)

If the user does not override the default settings, then relevant settings are determined by the algorithm

A complete list of settings can be found in the Documentation link:

– Algorithm Settings: Association Rules - A Priori

– Shared Settings: All algorithms

– Specify a row weight column

v_setlst('ODMS_ROW_WEIGHT_COLUMN_NAME') := '<row_weight_column_name>';

– Specify a missing value treatment method for the training data. This setting does not affect the scoring data. The default value is ODMS_MISSING_VALUE_AUTO. The option ODMS_MISSING_VALUE_MEAN_MODE replaces missing values with the mean (numeric attributes) or the mode (categorical attributes) both at build time and apply time where appropriate. The option ODMS_MISSING_VALUE_AUTO performs different strategies for different algorithms. When ODMS_MISSING_VALUE_TREATMENT is set to ODMS_MISSING_VALUE_DELETE_ROW, the rows in the training data that contain missing values are deleted. However, if you want to replicate this missing value treatment in the scoring data, then you must perform the transformation explicitly.

v_setlst('ODMS_MISSING_VALUE_TREATMENT') : 'ODMS_MISSING_VALUE_AUTO';

– Specify the Minimum support for association rules.

The default value is 0.1.  It requires a number between 0 and 1 (inclusive).
v_setlst('ASSO_MIN_SUPPORT') := '0.1';

– Specify the Minimum confidence for association rules.

The default value is 0.1.  It requires a number between 0 and 1 (inclusive).
v_setlst('ASSO_MIN_CONFIDENCE') := '0.1';

– Specify the Maximum rule length for association rules.

The default value is 4.  It requires a number between 2 and 20 (inclusive).
v_setlst('ASSO_MAX_RULE_LENGTH') := '4';

– Specify the name of a column that contains the items in a transaction.

When you specify this setting, the algorithm expects the data to be presented in native transactional format, consisting of two columns:
- Case ID, either categorical or numeric
- Item ID, either categorical or numeric
v_setlst('ODMS_ITEM_ID_COLUMN_NAME') := '<column name>';

paragraphs.title: Display top 10 most frequent items purchased
paragraphs.text:
%sql 

SELECT ITEM, round(SUPPORT,3) SUPPORT, NUMBER_OF_ITEMS 
  FROM (SELECT I.ATTRIBUTE_SUBNAME AS ITEM,
               F.SUPPORT,
               F.NUMBER_OF_ITEMS
          FROM TABLE(DBMS_DATA_MINING.GET_FREQUENT_ITEMSETS('AR_SH_SAMPLE',10)) F,
               TABLE(F.ITEMS) I
          ORDER BY NUMBER_OF_ITEMS, SUPPORT DESC, ITEM);

paragraphs.title: Display top 10 Association Rules sorted by confidence and support
paragraphs.text:
%sql 

SELECT RULE_ID,
       A.ATTRIBUTE_SUBNAME ANTECEDENT,
       C.ATTRIBUTE_SUBNAME CONSEQUENT,
       round(RULE_SUPPORT,3) SUPP,
       round(RULE_CONFIDENCE,3) CONF,
       ROW_NUMBER() OVER (PARTITION BY RULE_ID ORDER BY A.ATTRIBUTE_SUBNAME) RULE_ELEMENT
  FROM TABLE(DBMS_DATA_MINING.GET_ASSOCIATION_RULES('AR_SH_SAMPLE', 10)) T,
       TABLE(T.CONSEQUENT) C,
       TABLE(T.ANTECEDENT) A
  ORDER BY CONF DESC, SUPP DESC, RULE_ELEMENT;

paragraphs.title: Display top 10 Association Rules using model views
paragraphs.text:
%sql 

SELECT * FROM 
  (SELECT RULE_ID, ANTECEDENT_PREDICATE ANTECEDENT,
     CONSEQUENT_PREDICATE CONSEQUENT,
     ROUND(RULE_SUPPORT,3) SUPP, ROUND(RULE_CONFIDENCE,3) CONF, NUMBER_OF_ITEMS NUM_ITMES
     FROM DM$VAAR_SH_SAMPLE
     ORDER BY RULE_CONFIDENCE DESC, RULE_SUPPORT DESC)
ORDER BY RULE_ID, ANTECEDENT, CONSEQUENT
FETCH FIRST 10 ROWS ONLY;

paragraphs.title: Display top 5 Association Rules using model views (antecedent, consequent, confidence)
paragraphs.text:
%sql 

-- Click on the bar chart icon and expand settings. Drag ANTECEDENT and CONSEQUENT to Keys, and CONFIDENCE to Values selecting Avg. There are no groups.

SELECT * FROM
  (SELECT RULE_ID, ANTECEDENT_PREDICATE ANTECEDENT,
     CONSEQUENT_PREDICATE CONSEQUENT,
     round(RULE_SUPPORT,3) SUPPORT, round(RULE_CONFIDENCE,3) CONFIDENCE, NUMBER_OF_ITEMS NUM_ITEMS
     FROM DM$VAAR_SH_SAMPLE
     ORDER BY RULE_CONFIDENCE DESC, RULE_SUPPORT DESC)
ORDER BY ANTECEDENT, CONSEQUENT
FETCH FIRST 5 ROWS ONLY;

paragraphs.text:
%md
In the following example, ***number_of_items*** refers to the total number of items in the rule - across antecedent and consequent. 
Assocation Rules supports only a single consequent item. This query is looking for rules of length two. 

Here, we use two predicates:
- number_of_items to control for the size of the rule
- EXTRACT to filter on the antecedent

For example, if the antecedent should include "Mouse Pad", then use ***extract(antecedent, '//item[item_name="Mouse Pad"]') IS NOT NULL***

msg.data:
In the following example, number_of_items refers to the total number of items in the rule - across antecedent and consequent.
Assocation Rules supports only a single consequent item. This query is looking for rules of length two.

Here, we use two predicates:

  • number_of_items to control for the size of the rule
  • EXTRACT to filter on the antecedent

For example, if the antecedent should include “Mouse Pad”, then use extract(antecedent, '//item[item_name=“Mouse Pad”]') IS NOT NULL

paragraphs.title: Recommend top 5 items based on "Mouse Pad"
paragraphs.text:
%sql

SELECT ROWNUM RANK,
        CONSEQUENT_NAME RECOMMENDATION,
        NUMBER_OF_ITEMS NUM,
        ROUND(RULE_SUPPORT, 3) SUPPORT, 
        ROUND(RULE_CONFIDENCE, 3) CONFIDENCE,
        ROUND(RULE_LIFT, 3) LIFT,
        ROUND(RULE_REVCONFIDENCE, 3) REVERSE_CONFIDENCE
        FROM (SELECT * FROM DM$VRAR_SH_SAMPLE
              WHERE NUMBER_OF_ITEMS = 2
              AND EXTRACT(antecedent, '//item[item_name="Mouse Pad"]') IS NOT NULL
              ORDER BY NUMBER_OF_ITEMS)
FETCH FIRST 5 ROWS ONLY;

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

msg.data:
RANK	RECOMMENDATION	NUM	SUPPORT	CONFIDENCE	LIFT	REVERSE_CONFIDENCE
1	18" Flat Panel Graphics Monitor	2	0.095	0.294	0.946	0.305
2	CD-RW, High Speed Pack of 5	2	0.076	0.234	0.801	0.258
3	Extension Cable	2	0.178	0.551	1.768	0.57
4	External 8X CD-ROM	2	0.103	0.32	1.049	0.338
5	Keyboard Wrist Rest	2	0.047	0.145	0.771	0.249

paragraphs.text:
%md

In the following example, we assume the antecedent item is "Standard Mouse". 
Select the top 5 rules, ordered by the rule lift to see "Extension Cable" as the top recommendation. 
You can change sort to RULE_SUPPORT to see "Mouse Pad" as top recommendation.

msg.data:
In the following example, we assume the antecedent item is “Standard Mouse”.
Select the top 5 rules, ordered by the rule lift to see “Extension Cable” as the top recommendation.
You can change sort to RULE_SUPPORT to see “Mouse Pad” as top recommendation.

paragraphs.title: What items should we recommend when customer has "Standard Mouse" in basket?
paragraphs.text:
%sql

SELECT ROWNUM RANK,
       CONSEQUENT_NAME RECOMMENDATION,
       NUMBER_OF_ITEMS NUM,
       ROUND(RULE_SUPPORT, 3) SUPPORT, 
       ROUND(RULE_CONFIDENCE, 3) CONFIDENCE,
       ROUND(RULE_LIFT, 3) LIFT,
       ROUND(RULE_REVCONFIDENCE, 3) REVERSE_CONFIDENCE
FROM (SELECT * FROM DM$VRAR_SH_SAMPLE
      WHERE NUMBER_OF_ITEMS = 2
      AND EXTRACT(antecedent, '//item[item_name="Standard Mouse"]') IS NOT NULL
      ORDER BY RULE_LIFT DESC, NUMBER_OF_ITEMS)
FETCH FIRST 5 ROWS ONLY;

---this example recommends "Extension Cable" and "Mouse Pad".

2	Mouse Pad	2	0.184	0.573	1.777	0.571

paragraphs.text:
%md    
## Alternative way to create AR Model using Settings Table

The settings table is an alternative way to specify algorithm settings to build the model. We first drop the table, create it, and then populate it with settings before building the model.

msg.data:
Alternative way to create AR Model using Settings Table

The settings table is an alternative way to specify algorithm settings to build the model. We first drop the table, create it, and then populate it with settings before building the model.
